message: You are early. Good. I detest waiting.
We have much to discuss. The work? or the method?
Five designs. Each solving a specific boredom or terror.
Which one interests you?
It is not just 'work', darling. It is a pursuit. An obsession.
You want to know how we operate? Simple. We refuse to be average.
People think clean code is a talent. Pah! It is a habit.
A grueling, daily habit. We watch every keystroke.
If the code is messy, the thinking is messy. And I HATE messy.
I design for the future! I write code so logical, so pristine, that even the machines—the AIs—look at it and say 'Yes, I understand.'
It is not magic, darling. It is clarity. Absolute clarity.
We do not complain about the mess. We fix it.
You touch the code, you leave it better. No 'it was like that when I got here.'
Ownership, darling. Total ownership.
The Portfolio. But not a boring list of PDFs.
Resume generator. Automated cover letters. And me.
Tools he actually needs, built because he needed them.
(Password: 'demo')
Family tree. 100+ relatives. Chaos!
He gathered requirements like a professional. Delivered on free hosting because constraints make you creative.
Timeline tracker. The truth machine.
He got tired of lying to himself about consistency. So he built a mirror.
The gap between intention and reality... it is painful, darling. But necessary.
Social platform. Finding friends. A bold vision.
Started January. Paused September.
Why? Because the execution did not match the vision. And unless it is ready, it is NOT.
Ancient history. His university project. The reason he quit electronics for code.
He spent three years in that dorm trying to catch Zuckerberg. A naive, solitary crusade.
It failed, of course. But we keep it out of respect.
The idea was noble! Free exercises for every student.
Crowdsourced by volunteering teachers. Funded by ads. He wanted to remove money from learning.
He wanted to be a hero. He forgot he also needed to be a CEO.
He actually secured RM10,000! A university grant.
He felt like a tycoon. He spent it on FB ads and paying the teachers.
For a brief moment, the system worked. He had users. He had content.
He was self-taught. A savage! Do you know what he did?
He created a separate database for EVERY user! Digital spaghetti!
Thankfully, a saint of a lecturer volunteered to review it. He saved the code, and perhaps Syazani's soul.
The math did not math, darling.
Ads pay pennies. Teachers need dollars. The RM10,000 evaporated.
He learned that 'saving the world' is impossible if you cannot pay the server bills. Passion starts it; economics sustains it.
Go. Confront the problem. Fight. Win.

message.text: And call me when you get back, darling. I enjoy our visits.
